APCATA 15701 S0926-860X(15)30301-X 10.1016/j.apcata.2015.12.028 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Scheme of deposition of Co3O4 nanoclusters onto carbon spheres. Fig. 2 FESEM and TEM images of (a–d) Co/C-400 and (e, f) Co/C-300 prepared by impregnation method. The inset in (f) shows the high resolution TEM image of cobalt oxide nanoparticles on the surface of carbon spheres. Fig. 3 (a) STEM image and (b-d) EDX mapping of Co/C-300 nanocatalyst. Fig. 4 Raman spectra of Co/C-300 and Co/C-400 nanocatalysts. Fig. 5 XPS spectra of Co/C-300 nanocatalyst, (a) C 1s, (b) Co 2p, and (c) O 1s. Fig. 6 XPS spectra of Co/C-400 nanocatalyst, (a) C 1s, (b) Co 2p, and (c) O 1s. Fig. 7 (a, b) FESEM and (c, d) TEM images of Co/C-DP prepared by precipitation–deposition method. Fig. 8 Raman spectrum of Co/C-DP nanocatalyst. Fig. 9 XPS spectra of Co/C-DP nanocatalysts, (a) C 1s, (b) Co 2p, and (c) O 1s. Fig. 10 TEM images of (a, b) Co/C-600 and (c, d) Co/C-800. Fig. 11 (a) XRD patterns and (b) Raman spectra of Co/C-600 and Co/C-800. Fig. 12 (a, b) Methyl orange degradation with carbon spheres supported Co3O4 nanocatalysts. Reaction condition: methyl orange (5mg), deionized water (100mL), oxone (14mg), catalyst (10mg). Purple (Co/C-300) and blue (Co/C-DP) lines represent control reactions performed without oxidant added. Fig. 13 Catalytic stability of Co/C-300 nanocatalysts for methyl orange degradation. Carbon spheres anchored Co3O4 nanoclusters as an efficient catalyst for dye degradation Jian Dou a Shengming Yin a Jeng Yi Chong a Bowei Zhang b Jianyu Han a Yizhong Huang b Rong Xu a ⁎ a School of Chemical & Biomedical Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, 62 Nanyang Drive, 637459, Singapore School of Chemical & Biomedical Engineering Nanyang Technological University 62 Nanyang Drive 637459 Singapore b School of Materials Science and Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Avenue, 639798, Singapore School of Materials Science and Engineering Nanyang Technological University 50 Nanyang Avenue 639798 Singapore ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cobalt oxide nanoparticles with sizes of 1–2 nm were immobilized on carbon spheres support. Surface cobalt species were stabilized via coordination with surface hydroxyl groups of carbon spheres. Small cobalt oxide nanoclusters were very active for oxidative dye degradation. Herein, we have developed an effective strategy to immobilize spinel cobalt oxide (Co3O4) particles of nanometer and subnanometer sizes on carbon sphere support via impregnation and deposition-precipitation methods. With carbon spheres support, very small Co3O4 nanoparticles of around 1–2nm are uniformly distributed on the surface. Based on XPS analysis, the surface cobalt species are found coordinated with hydroxyl groups from carbon spheres. Among the various catalysts investigated, the Co/C-300 nanocatalyst with 1–2nm cobalt oxide clusters exhibits the highest activity with over 99% of methyl orange degraded in less than 10min of reaction. The higher activity of Co/C-300 nanocatalyst was attributed to small size of Co3O4 nanoparticles with more surface sites exposed for dye degradation reaction. The Co/C-300 nanocatalyst is reasonably stable and could be recycled for at least four runs without losing activity substantially. Keywords Spinel oxide Nanoclusters Carbon spheres Dye Degradation 1 Introduction Nanocatalysis has received growing research interests in the field of materials chemistry and catalysis over the last decades [1–3]. With advancement of materials science and nanotechnology, nanocatalysts can be prepared with well controlled size, shape, composition and structure. These properties are key factors for designing next generation nanocatalysts with high activity and high selectivity [2]. Furthermore, assembly of nanoparticles onto suitable catalyst supports holds the key for the practical application of nanocatalysts, which bridges the gap between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. There are several strategies available to assemble nanoparticles onto catalyst supports such as deposition of nanoparticles or metal salts precursors onto pre-synthesized catalyst supports, co-precipitation of metal/metal oxide with catalyst supports and synthesis of catalyst supports in the presence of nanoparticles [1]. Cobalt metal and cobalt oxides/cobalt hydroxides (i.e., Co, Co3O4, CoO, and Co(OH)2) are important inorganic materials for wide applications such as sensors, magnetism, lithium-ion batteries, and catalysis [4–13]. There are many supported cobalt/cobalt oxides catalysts applied in industrial processes as well as reported in the literature for various catalytic applications. For example, alumina supported cobalt/molybdenum oxides activated by hydrogen sulfide has been used in refinery plants as hydrodesulfurization catalyst for removing sulfur from transportation oil [11]. Silica or alumina supported cobalt metal catalysts have been applied for Fischer–Tropsch process for producing hydrocarbons from carbon monoxide and hydrogen [12,13]. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles with sizes of 1–20nm have been deposited onto metal oxide supports such as SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, TiO2 etc [4,14–17]. Carbonaceous spheres synthesized from hydrothermal treatment of mono- or polysaccharides have unique properties such as well defined morphology and size [18–20]. As-synthesized carbon spheres are generally non-porous, while micropores and/or mesopores can be generated by thermal treatment at high temperature in inert gas atmosphere [21]. Due to rich surface functional groups such as hydroxyl, carbonyl, and carboxylic species, carbon spheres are promising candidate as a new type catalyst support. For instance, carbon spheres have been used as support for immobilizing metal, metal oxides, and metal sulfides such as Ag, Pd, Fe3O4 and CdS etc [18]. Cobalt metal nanoparticles with sizes of around 5nm have also been deposited onto carbon spheres via colloid deposition and CVD methods [12,22]. Much smaller cobalt hydroxide nanoparticles with sizes of 1–2nm have been immobilized onto colloidal silica by a deposition-precipitation method [23]. However, it remains challenging to immobilize cobalt oxide or hydroxide nanoparticles with sizes of 1–2nm onto carbon spheres, as thermal treatment in air associated with the conventional impregnation method leads to aggregation of cobalt oxide nanoparticles. Organic dyes are widely used in textile, paper and food industry. The annual production of dyestuffs is estimated to be around one million tons worldwide [24]. The largest amount of organic dyes is used for dyeing of textiles. In such a process, about 10% of the dyestuffs is released to the environment due to improper binding to the fibers [24,25]. The conventional strategies for purification of dyeing wastewater are based on separation processes such as adsorption, coagulation, filtration and ion exchange [26]. The adsorbed or precipitated dye compounds have to be removed to regenerate the adsorbent or membrane. With more stringent regulations, many research efforts have been devoted to developing efficient processes such as microbiological treatments, enzymatic decomposition and electrochemical methods to remove dyes from polluted water [26]. Particularly, advanced oxidation process (AOP) is a powerful oxidation method based on the generation of highly reactive hydroxyl or sulfate radicals to decompose dyes [25]. Oxone is a versatile oxidant for oxidative degradation of many organic compounds [27]. Oxone can be activated by transition metal cations such as Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+ and Cu2+ to generate sulfate radicals, which is a strong oxidant for decomposition of organic dyes. Among the various transition metals, cobalt is the most active for coupling with oxone [28]. Many cobalt oxide (i.e., Co3O4) based heterogeneous catalysts either supported or unsupported have been explored for activation of oxone [4,29–33]. Particularly, it was found that the support has a significant effect on the activity of supported cobalt catalyst. With Co3O4 supported on MgO, the activity is four times higher that cobalt oxide supported on ZnO, P25, Al2O3, and SBA-15 [4]. It is our aim to further explore the effects of other catalyst parameters such particle size of cobalt oxide nanoparticles to improve the efficiency of cobalt based catalysts for dye degradation. In this work, cobalt oxide nanoparticles are successfully deposited onto the surface of carbon spheres via impregnation and deposition-precipitation methods (Fig. 1 ). The particle size of the deposited cobalt oxide nanoparticles can be adjusted by heating Co/C samples in argon at various temperature (300–800°C). The as-prepared Co/C nanocatalysts were investigated for organic dye degradation and have demonstrated excellent activities. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of carbon spheres Carbon spheres with an average size of around 120nm were prepared following literature methods with some modifications [20,34]. Briefly, 80mL of 0.5M glucose (C6H12O6, Sigma–Aldrich) aqueous solution was placed into a Teflon liner with a capacity of 120mL. The Teflon liner was fitted into an autoclave, which was then heated in oven at 160°C for 12h. The dark brown suspension was filtered and washed with deionized water. The collected solid sample was dried at 60°C in oven for overnight. 2.2 Deposition of Co3O4 clusters and nanoparticles onto carbon spheres The prepared carbon spheres were used as catalyst supports for deposition of cobalt oxide nanoclusters and nanoparticles via impregnation and deposition-precipitation methods. In a typical impregnation method, 42mg of cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O) was firstly dissolved in 0.12mL of deionized water. After that, 100mg of carbon spheres were impregnated with above prepared cobalt acetate aqueous solution. The impregnated sample was dried at 60°C for overnight and later heated at 300–800°C for 3h in argon. To immobilize cobalt oxide onto carbon spheres via deposition-precipitation method, 100mg of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) was firstly dissolved in 200mL of deionized water. After that, 200mg of carbon spheres were dispersed in above cobalt nitrate solution, followed by adding 2mL of 20% ammonia aqueous solution. The resultant mixture was refluxed at 90°C in an oil bath for 2 days. The solid product was collected by filtration and washing with deionized water, followed by drying at 60°C overnight. 2.3 Degradation of methyl orange Methyl orange (C14H14N3NaO3S) was used as a model compound for dye degradation reaction. Typically, 100mL of 50ppm (ppm: mg/L) methyl orange solution was added into a beaker with 200mL of capacity. After that, 10mg of catalyst and 14mg of oxone (2KHSO5·KHSO4·K2SO4, Alfa Aesar, 4.7% active oxygen) were added to above methyl orange solution consecutively. The resulted mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30min. At different time intervals (i.e., 2, 5, 10, 15, 20 and 30min), 2mL of reaction mixture was taken and filtered for analyzing the concentration of methyl orange by UV–vis spectroscopy (Shimadzu 2450). For recycle test, the used catalyst was recovered by filtering the reaction mixture after reaction and washed with deionized water. The spent catalyst was dried at 60°C overnight before the next run. 2.4 Materials characterization The crystallographic structures of the prepared Co3O4/C samples were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D2, CuKα, λ =1.5406Å). The morphology and chemical composition of the Co/C nanocatalysts were studied using field emission scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (FESEM/EDX, JSM6701F), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM2010, 300kV), and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM2100, 200kV). The weight percentage of cobalt was measured on An Agilent 7700x Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP). The oxidation states of supported cobalt oxide nanoclusters and nanoparticles were examined with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, AXIS-HSi, Kratos Analytical) using a monochromatized Al Kα exciting radiation (1486.71eV), and all binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C 1s peak at 284.6eV. Raman spectra of Co/C samples were collected on Renishaw InVia Reflex Raman Spectroscopy in the back scattering configuration with the excitation wavelength line of 633nm in air ambient environment. The power of the excitation laser lines was kept below 1mW to avoid heating effect. The Raman emission was collected by a Leica 50x objective (N.A.=0.5) over three randomly selected spots on the powder. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst Properties Carbon spheres supported cobalt oxide nanoparticles were prepared by impregnation of aqueous solution of cobalt precursor salt (i.e., cobalt acetate) followed by thermal treatment in argon at 300–800°C for 3h. The FESEM image in Fig. 2 a shows that the morphology of cobalt oxide deposited carbon spheres after heat treatment at 400°C (i.e., Co/C-400) remains similar as that of the as-synthesized carbon spheres. At the higher magnification, aggregates of small nanoparticles can be observed on the surface of carbon spheres (Fig. 2b), indicating the formation of cobalt oxide nanoparticles by decomposition of cobalt precursor during thermal treatment. Fig. 2b and 2d presents the TEM images of the same sample. It can be seen that cobalt oxide nanoparticles with sizes of 3–5nm are well dispersed on the surface of carbon spheres. When the thermal treatment temperature was reduced to 300°C, the formed cobalt oxide nanoparticles had very small sizes and were only observed under high resolution TEM examination (Fig. 2e and f). It has been reported that cobalt acetate and cobalt nitrate precursors can decompose below 300°C by extended heating [35]. Hence it is possible that the cobalt oxide nanoclusters formed by decomposition of cobalt acetate at such a low temperature are too small to be observed by TEM. HRTEM analysis was carried out to confirm their existence on the surface of carbon spheres. As shown in the inset in Fig. 2f, cobalt oxide nanoparticles with sizes of 1–2nm can be observed. The lattice spacing of 0.24nm can be attributed to (311) plane of cubic Co3O4 (JCPDS 42–1467), which will be further confirmed by Raman analysis later. In order to understand the distribution of cobalt oxide nanoparticles on the carbon surface, EDX mapping was carried out under scanning TEM (STEM) mode on randomly selected carbon sphere of Co/C-300 nanocatalysts (Fig. 3 a). As shown in Fig. 3b-d, all the three elements (C, Co and O) are uniformly distributed on the carbon surface, suggesting the current synthesis strategy is effective to immobilize very small cobalt oxide nanoparticles on the surface of carbon spheres. The measured weight percentage of cobalt in Co/C-300 and Co/C-400 is around 7.5% and 8.6% which are slightly lower than the theoretical value of 10%. The above two carbon spheres supported cobalt oxide samples, Co/C-300 and Co/C-400, were further characterized by XRD (Fig. S1). There are no peaks observed for both Co/C-300 and Co/C-400 nanocatalysts, possibly due to small cobalt oxide nanoclusters and nanoparticles uniformly dispersed on the surface of carbon spheres or poor crystallinity of formed cobalt oxide nanoparticles. Raman spectroscopy was used to further support the existence of deposited Co3O4 nanoclusters and nanoparticles on the surface of carbon spheres. As shown in Fig. 4 , three peaks at 468, 513, and 674cm−1 appear in the spectrum of Co/C-400 sample, which can be attributed to E g, F 2g, and A 1g mode of Co3O4 nanoparticles [36–38]. For Co/C-300 sample, only two peaks at 468 and 671cm−1 can be observed, correlating to Eg and A1g mode of Co3O4 nanoclusters. The peak at 513cm−1 due to F 2g mode of Co3O4 is not obvious, possibly due to the very small particle sizes. The oxidation states of supported cobalt oxide nanoparticles were examined by XPS technique. In the spectrum of C 1s of sample Co/C-300 (Fig. 5 a), the first peak at 284.6eV is assigned to CC bond, while the second peak at 286.3eV is attributed to carbon coordinated to OH or in COC groups. The third peak at 288.5eV is due to surface COOH and COO groups [21]. The spectrum of Co 2p3/2 can be deconvoluted to two pairs of peaks (Fig. 5b). The two major peaks at 781.4 and 783.9eV could be assigned to cobalt cations associated with OH and COO groups, respectively, which is consistent with existence of abundant surface OH and COO groups on the surface of carbon spheres [4,39]. The two corresponding shake-up satellite peaks are centered at 786.9 and 789.4eV, respectively. For O 1s spectrum, the first peak at 530.7 is ascribed to the lattice oxygen in cobalt oxides or oxygen marked with an asterisk in surface CO*O groups (Fig. 5c). The second peak at 532.1eV can be assigned to surface hydroxyl group, and the last peak at 533.6eV is attributed to oxygen marked with an asterisk in COO* functional groups [21]. It is noted that the surface of carbon spheres is rich in hydroxyl groups based on the peak areas of deconvoluted O 1s peak. It has been reported that most oxides are hydroxylated when exposed to moisture, and the extent of hydroxylation depends on the nature of metal ions involved and also on the surrounding environmental [40,41]. For instance, most surface cobalt ions are associated with hydroxyl group when supported on magnesium oxide [4]. It is known that surface of carbon spheres synthesized from hydrothermal treatment of glucose is abundant with hydroxyl groups [20,21]. Thus it explains that surface cobalt ions on carbon spheres are mainly associated with hydroxyl groups. For the sample Co/C-400 calcined at 400°C, the C 1s and O 1s spectra are similar as those of Co/C-300 sample (Fig. 6 a and c). In cobalt 2p3/2 spectrum, the peaks at 782.0 and 784.1eV can be assigned to cobalt cations coordinated with hydroxyl and carboxylate groups respectively as discussed previously (Fig. 6b). It is noted that after heating at 400°C in argon, a higher percentage of cobalt species are associated with carboxylate groups. Carbon spheres supported Co3O4 nanoclusters were also prepared by deposition-precipitation method (i.e., Co/C-DP). As shown in Fig. 7 a and b, carbon spheres with sizes of around 150nm together with small particles on their surface can be observed after deposition of cobalt species. It is noted that the precipitation-deposition process was carried out by treating the carbon spheres in the aqueous solution added with cobalt nitrate and ammonia and the mixture was aged at 90°C for 2d. The loosen particles on the carbon surface could be the broken carbon species from carbon spheres. Based on the TEM images (Fig. 7C and d), it is clearly seen that broken carbon species co-exist with carbon spheres. Similar to the sample Co/C-300 prepared by the impregnation method, there are no Co3O4 nanoparticles observed on the surface of carbon spheres, indicating that the size of cobalt based nanoparticles is too small and they are uniformly dispersed on the surface of carbon spheres. The weight percentage of cobalt in this sample was measured to be 6.9% by ICP. The samples prepared by precipitation-deposition method were further characterized by XRD and Raman spectroscopy. As expected, there is no peak observed in the XRD pattern of Co/C-DP, which is similar as those of Co/C-300 and Co/C-400 prepared via the impregnation method (Figure S1). As discussed above, it is possibly due to the small Co3O4 nanoclusters uniformly dispersed on the surface of carbon spheres. Raman spectrum (Fig. 8 ) shows that two peaks can be observed at 467 and 663cm−1, which were attributed to E g and A 1g mode of spinel Co3O4, which is similar to that of Co/C-300. It shows both impregnation and precipitation-deposition methods can be used for deposition of very small (probably <1nm) Co3O4 nanoclusters onto carbon spheres. Fig. 9 presents the XPS results of Co/C-DP. In the spectrum of C 1s, the first major peak at 284.6eV is assigned to CC bond, and the second at 286.5eV is attributed to surface OH or COC groups. The last peak at 288.6eV could be attributed to surface COOH and COO groups, as discussed above. For Co 2p3/2 spectrum, the two major peaks at 781.4 and 783.9eV could be assigned to cobalt cations associated with hydroxyl and carboxylate groups respectively. As discussed above, majority of surface cobalt ions coordinated with hydroxyl groups, which presented abundantly on the surface of carbon spheres. The assignment of O 1s peaks was similar as that of Co/C-300 and Co/C-400 nanocatalysts. It can be observed that the hydroxyl group in Co/C-CP sample is relatively more abundant than that in Co/C samples, which is probably due to the interaction of carbon spheres with the alkaline solution during the precipitation process [34]. Based on above results, it is known that the sizes of immobilized Co3O4 nanoparticles in Co/C-300 and Co/C-400 samples prepared via impregnation method vary between about 1 to 5nm by changing the heating temperature. The effect of thermal treatment temperature was further studied by heating the impregnated sample at 600 and 800°C. As shown in Fig. 10 a and b, large cobalt/cobalt oxide particles of 20–100nm can be observed coexisting with 5nm nanoparticles. It was known that carbonization of carbon spheres occurs at temperature above 500°C, along with losing surface functional groups (i.e., OH) [21]. The surface hydroxyl groups are essential to coordinate with Co species and thus stabilize the small cobalt oxide nanoclusters. With decreased surface OH groups, the surface cobalt nanoclusters tend to aggregate and form larger crystals with sizes of 20–100nm. Further increasing the calcination temperature to 800°C, only large cobalt/cobalt oxide particles with size of 20 to 100nm can be observed, which is due to aggregation and recrystallization of surface cobalt oxide nanoclusters after the loss of most of the surface OH groups. Furthermore, it is interesting to find that in the XRD pattern of Co/C-800 nanocatalyst (Fig. 11 a), three peaks appeared at 44.4, 51.8 and 76.2° can be assigned to (111), (200) and (220) planes of cubic cobalt metal phase (JCPDS #15-0806). Self-reduction of cobalt cation occurs at high temperature with consuming surface functional groups (i.e., OH) on the surface carbon spheres. The FTIR spectra of Co/C samples calcined at 300 and 800°C was presented in Fig. S2. It can be seen that the surface functional groups such as OH and CO are greatly reduced after thermal treatment at 800°C, which was due to consumption of surface functional groups for reduction of Co3O4 and also for carbonization of carbon spheres. No peaks can be observed in the XRD pattern of Co/C-600. The lack of XRD peaks for this sample is possibly due to the percentage of large cobalt/cobalt oxide particles is much less compared to that of 5nm nanoparticles. On the other hand, in Raman spectra (Fig. 11b) the four characteristics peaks of spinel Co3O4 can be observed at 463, 509, 605, and 669cm−1 for both samples, though the spectrum of Co/C-600 is much weaker. It suggests that the surface layers of metallic cobalt nanocrystals are oxidized to Co3O4, since cobalt metal can be easily oxidized in air. 3.2 Methyl orange degradation The thus prepared carbon spheres supported Co3O4 were investigated for oxidation of organic dye. In present work, methyl orange was used as the model dye compound and oxone was chosen as the oxidant. The oxidant to methyl orange ratio (KHSO5: C14H14N3NaO3S) was fixed as 3:1. The adsorption capability of the prepared catalysts (i.e., Co/C-300 and Co/C-DP) was firstly investigated without adding oxone. As shown in Fig. 12 a, less than 5% of methyl orange can be adsorbed on the catalyst surface, which should be due to non-porous structure of carbon spheres support. The Co/C-300 nanocatalyst with around 1–2nm Co3O4 nanoclusters supported on carbon spheres exhibits excellent activity for dye degradation and was the most active among all the samples tested (Fig. 12a). At the reaction time of 2min, around 70% methyl orange can be oxidized. The conversion is increased to 91 and 99% at 5 and 10min, respectively. The effect of adsorption alone on reducing the dye concentration is insignificant as indicated by the curves in the absence of oxone shown in Fig. 12a. For the Co/C-400 nanocatalyst calcined at 400°C, the degradation of methyl orange is around 46% and 80% at 2 and 5min respectively. The lower activity should be due to the increased particle sizes of Co3O4 and the reduced OH groups. For Co/C-600 nanocatalyst, the activity is further reduced with around 50 and 70% of methyl orange degraded at 2 and 5min. The sample prepared by precipitation-deposition method (Co/C-DP) has the lowest activity among the samples evaluated. The conversion of methyl orange at 5min was measured to be 50%. The kinetics of dye degradation has been studied by plotting ln(C/C0) vs time (Fig. 12b). By assuming a pseudo first-order reaction, the kinetic constants were calculated to be 0.54, 0.39, 0.2, and 0.16min−1 for Co/C-300, Co/C-400, Co/C-600, and Co/C-DP catalysts respectively. Many transition metal oxides based catalysts (i.e., Co3O4, MnO2, and CuO) have been developed for dye degradation [42–50]. It shall be mentioned that it is difficult to directly compare the activities of various catalysts, as the experiment conditions such as types of dye and oxidants, and oxidant to dye ratio differ from one another. The activity of the best catalyst (i.e., Co/C-300) was calculated to be 1.21mg of methyl orange degraded per mg of cobalt metal per min at reaction time of 5min. It is known that CoO x /MgO catalyst reported earlier by our group was much more active for degradation of organic dyes than cobalt oxide deposited on other supports (i.e., Al2O3, ZnO, and ZrO2 etc.) [4]. The activity of CoO x /MgO catalyst was calculated to be 0.14mg of dye degraded per mg of cobalt metal per min at reaction time of 5min. It shall be mentioned that the size of cobalt oxide on MgO support is 5–10nm, which is much larger than the size of cobalt oxide nanoparticles on carbon spheres. This explains the 8 times higher activity of Co/C-300 nanocatalyst. The effect of pH on the activity for degradation of methyl orange was further studied with Co/C-300 nanocatalyst. As shown in Figure S3, the activity increased with the increasing pH value from 5 to 10. This observation is consistent with our previous results showing that basic MgO supported Co3O4 nanoparticles exhibited the highest activity for methyl orange degradation, which is possibly due to promotion effect of surface hydroxyl group.4 It has been reported that both SO4 −· and OH· radicals could be formed over transition metal catalysts [51–55]. We thus proposed the following mechanism for methyl orange degradation over Co/C nanocatalysts. Co2+ +HSO5 − →Co3+ +OH− +SO4 −· Co2+ +HSO5 − →Co3+ +SO4 2− +OH· Co3+ +HSO5 − →Co2+ +SO5 −·+H+ SO4 −·+MO→SO4 2− +intermediates→→CO2 +H2O OH·+MO→OH− +intermediates→→CO2 +H2O Firstly, sulfate radicals (SO4 −·) and hydroxyl radicals (OH·) are generated by oxidation Co2+ to Co3+ with peroxymonosulfate. Then, the oxidized Co3+ could further react with peroxymonosulfate to form Co2+ and peroxymonosulfate radicals (SO5 −·). The formed radicals (i.e., SO4 −· and OH·) are strong oxidants for degradation of methyl orange to intermediates and finally to carbon dioxide and water. As the redox potential of peroxomonosulfate radicals is relative weak, they may not be involved in degradation of methyl orange [53]. In addition, quenching of radicals may occur to reduce the radicals formed, which will slow the reaction for dye degradation [51]. The stability of Co/C-300 nanocatalyst was studied by recycling the used catalyst for four runs. As shown in Fig. 13 , the conversion of methyl orange is 90% and 100% at reaction time of 5 and 10min in the first run. In the second run, the conversion of methyl orange is dropped to 71% at reaction time of 10min and stabilized at 62–63% at 3rd and 4th run. Besides the possibility of losing some particles during filtration and washing, the partial activity loss could be due to dissolution of cobalt oxide as the reaction solution is slightly acidic because the use of oxone. Nevertheless, over 95% of conversion can still be achieved at 30min at the 4th run. 4 Conclusions In summary, carbon spheres supported Co3O4 nanocatalysts have been prepared by impregnation and precipitation-deposition methods. With low calcination temperatures of 300–400°C, nanometer or sub-nanometer sized Co3O4 clusters can be uniformly deposited on the surface of carbon spheres. The carbon spheres supported Co3O4 nanocatalysts were investigated for methyl orange degradation reaction. Among all the prepared catalysts, Co/C-300 is the most active catalyst. At a reaction time of 5min, 91% of methyl orange can be oxidized, and a total conversion is achieved at 10min. Furthermore, the Co/C-300 nanocatalyst is reasonably stable and could be recycled for several runs. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we have developed an effective strategy to immobilize spinel cobalt oxide (Co3O4) particles of nanometer and subnanometer sizes on carbon sphere support via impregnation and deposition-precipitation methods. With carbon spheres support, very small Co3O4 nanoparticles of around 1–2nm are uniformly distributed on the surface. Based on XPS analysis, the surface cobalt species are found coordinated with hydroxyl groups from carbon spheres. Among the various catalysts investigated, the Co/C-300 nanocatalyst with 1–2nm cobalt oxide clusters exhibits the highest activity with over 99% of methyl orange degraded in less than 10min of reaction. The higher activity of Co/C-300 nanocatalyst was attributed to small size of Co3O4 nanoparticles with more surface sites exposed for dye degradation reaction. The Co/C-300 nanocatalyst is reasonably stable and could be recycled for at least four runs without losing activity substantially.
coredata.dc:title: Carbon spheres anchored Co3O4 nanoclusters as an efficient catalyst for dye degradation
